newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Caracas stocks hit record high despite rates rise.
newsitem.headline: Caracas stocks hit record high despite rates rise.

text.p: Caracas stocks pushed ahead, despite a five-point increase in interest rates, to close at a record high in a session propelled by foreign buying of oversold blue chips, traders said.
The market's 19-share index gained 0.62 percent to end at 4,610.37, busting technical resistance at the previous twelve-month high of 4,582.03, according to preliminary figures from the exchange.
Among traded issues, 28 stocks rose, eight fell and five closed flat.
Nearly 14 million shares traded worth 2.23 billion bolivars ($4.7 million).
"Interest was particularly high in Mavesa and Sivensa," said Activalores broker Gonzalo Alonso.
Food company Mavesa gained 5.95 bolivars to end at 117.95, while steel producer Sivensa added 10.00 bolivars to 310.00.
Brokers see the upwards trend of the past three days being sustained -- despite the rise in TEM yields at today's auction.
"It's been a while since interest rates had any strong effect on the bolsa," said one trader.
